_link.title: I can draw a plasma membrane and label all key components

toLevel2.question: In a plasma membrane diagram, which direction should the phospholipid heads face?

options.text: Outward, towards the watery environments on both sides
options.explanation: Phospholipid heads are hydrophilic and face outward towards the extracellular fluid (top) and intracellular fluid (bottom).

options.text: Inward, towards the centre of the bilayer
options.explanation: The heads are hydrophilic and face outward towards water, not inward. The hydrophobic tails face inward.

options.text: Only towards the outside of the cell surface
options.explanation: Phospholipid heads face outward on both sides of the bilayer, not just the outer surface.

options.text: In random directions throughout the bilayer
options.explanation: Phospholipid heads are consistently oriented outward on both sides due to their hydrophilic nature.

toLevel2.question: Which component should be drawn between the phospholipids in a plasma membrane diagram?

options.text: Cholesterol molecules
options.explanation: Cholesterol molecules are embedded between phospholipids in the bilayer and should be included in a complete membrane diagram.

options.text: Ribosome subunits
options.explanation: Ribosomes are not part of the plasma membrane; they are found in the cytoplasm or on the rough ER.

options.text: DNA strands
options.explanation: DNA is found in the nucleus or nucleoid region, not between phospholipids in the plasma membrane.

options.text: Cellulose fibres
options.explanation: Cellulose is a component of the cell wall in plants, not the plasma membrane.

toLevel2.question: What are glycoproteins on the plasma membrane?

options.text: Proteins with carbohydrate chains attached
options.explanation: Glycoproteins are membrane proteins that have carbohydrate chains attached to their extracellular surface.

options.text: Lipids with phosphate groups attached to them
options.explanation: Lipids with phosphate groups are phospholipids, not glycoproteins. Glycoproteins are proteins with carbohydrate chains.

options.text: Cholesterol molecules bonded to fatty acids
options.explanation: Cholesterol bonded to fatty acids does not describe glycoproteins, which are proteins with attached carbohydrates.

options.text: Free-floating ribosomes near the membrane
options.explanation: Ribosomes are separate structures; glycoproteins are membrane proteins with carbohydrate chains.

toLevel2.question: What is the difference between transmembrane proteins and peripheral proteins in a membrane diagram?

options.text: Transmembrane proteins span the entire bilayer while peripheral proteins sit on one surface
options.explanation: Transmembrane (integral) proteins extend through both layers of the bilayer, while peripheral proteins are attached to one surface of the membrane.

options.text: Peripheral proteins span the bilayer while transmembrane proteins sit on one surface only
options.explanation: This reverses the definitions: transmembrane proteins span the bilayer, and peripheral proteins are on one surface.

options.text: Both types are identical and are drawn the same way in all membrane diagrams
options.explanation: Transmembrane and peripheral proteins have different positions in the membrane and should be drawn differently.

options.text: Transmembrane proteins are carbohydrates while peripheral proteins are phospholipids in the membrane
options.explanation: Both transmembrane and peripheral proteins are proteins, not carbohydrates or phospholipids.

toLevel2.question: How should the phospholipid tails be drawn in a plasma membrane diagram?

options.text: As two wavy lines pointing inward from each head
options.explanation: Each phospholipid has two fatty acid tails that should be drawn as wavy lines pointing inward towards the centre of the bilayer.

options.text: As single straight lines pointing outward from each head
options.explanation: Each phospholipid has two tails (not one), and they point inward (not outward) towards the bilayer centre.

options.text: As circles on the opposite side of the membrane from the heads
options.explanation: The tails are represented as lines, not circles. Circles represent the phospholipid heads.

options.text: As arrows pointing in random directions from each head
options.explanation: Tails consistently point inward towards the bilayer centre, not in random directions.

toLevel2.question: A complete plasma membrane diagram should include phospholipids, proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrate chains.
toLevel2.explanation: A complete drawing includes all four key components: phospholipids forming the bilayer, transmembrane and peripheral proteins, cholesterol between phospholipids, and carbohydrate chains on glycoproteins and glycolipids.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: In a membrane diagram, the phospholipid tails should face outward towards the aqueous environments.
toLevel2.explanation: The phospholipid tails are hydrophobic and face inward towards the centre of the bilayer, away from the aqueous environments. The heads face outward.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: Phospholipid {{blank:1}} are drawn as circles facing outward, while the {{blank:2}} are drawn as wavy lines pointing inward.
{{blank:1}} proteins span the entire bilayer, while {{blank:2}} proteins are found on only one surface of the membrane.
Carbohydrate chains attached to proteins form {{blank:1}}, while carbohydrate chains attached to lipids form {{blank:2}}.

toLevel3.question: Why are phospholipid heads drawn facing outward on both sides of the bilayer in a membrane diagram?

options.text: Because the heads are hydrophilic and are attracted to the aqueous environments on both sides
options.explanation: Phospholipid heads are hydrophilic and orient towards the water-based environments (extracellular fluid and cytoplasm) on both sides of the membrane.

options.text: Because the heads need to be exposed to sunlight for the membrane to function properly
options.explanation: Phospholipid orientation is determined by hydrophilic and hydrophobic interactions with water, not sunlight exposure.

options.text: Because the heads are hydrophobic and must avoid contact with the membrane interior region
options.explanation: The heads are hydrophilic (water-attracting), not hydrophobic. They face outward towards water.

options.text: Because the heads are larger than the tails and can only fit on the outside of the bilayer
options.explanation: The outward orientation is due to hydrophilic interactions, not physical size differences.

toLevel3.question: Explain the role of cholesterol in the plasma membrane and why it is drawn between phospholipids.

options.text: Cholesterol stabilises the membrane by regulating fluidity between the phospholipid tails
options.explanation: Cholesterol sits between phospholipid tails, preventing them from packing too tightly or moving too freely, thereby regulating membrane fluidity.

options.text: Cholesterol provides energy to the membrane proteins so they can carry out active transport
options.explanation: Cholesterol regulates membrane structure, not energy supply. ATP provides energy for active transport.

options.text: Cholesterol replaces damaged phospholipids to maintain the bilayer structure at all times
options.explanation: Cholesterol does not replace phospholipids; it is positioned between them to regulate fluidity.

options.text: Cholesterol forms channels through the membrane for water molecules to pass through directly
options.explanation: Cholesterol does not form transport channels; it regulates membrane fluidity by interacting with phospholipid tails.

toLevel3.question: Why are carbohydrate chains only found on the outer surface of the plasma membrane?

options.text: They function in cell recognition and signalling, which requires exposure to the extracellular environment
options.explanation: Carbohydrate chains on glycoproteins and glycolipids serve as identification markers and signalling molecules, so they face the extracellular environment.

options.text: Carbohydrate chains are too large to fit inside the cell and must remain on the outside always
options.explanation: Their external position is due to their functional role in cell recognition and signalling, not physical size constraints.

options.text: Carbohydrate chains are hydrophobic and are repelled by the cytoplasm inside the cell
options.explanation: Carbohydrates are hydrophilic, not hydrophobic. Their external position relates to their function in cell-to-cell communication.

options.text: Carbohydrate chains are found on both surfaces equally but are only visible on the outside
options.explanation: Carbohydrate chains of glycoproteins and glycolipids are specifically located on the extracellular surface, not on both sides.

toLevel3.question: How does a transmembrane protein differ from a peripheral protein in terms of function?

options.text: Transmembrane proteins often form transport channels while peripheral proteins assist with signalling or structural support
options.explanation: Transmembrane proteins span the bilayer and can form channels or carriers for transport, while peripheral proteins on the surface often participate in signalling or provide structural support.

options.text: Both types of proteins perform identical functions and differ only in their colour in diagrams
options.explanation: Transmembrane and peripheral proteins have different positions and often different functions within the membrane.

options.text: Peripheral proteins transport substances across the membrane while transmembrane proteins do not
options.explanation: Transmembrane proteins are the ones that typically facilitate transport across the bilayer because they span both layers.

options.text: Transmembrane proteins are made of lipids while peripheral proteins are made of carbohydrates only
options.explanation: Both types are proteins made of amino acids; they are not made of lipids or carbohydrates.

toLevel3.question: Why is it important to label the extracellular and intracellular sides when drawing the plasma membrane?

options.text: It shows the orientation of components like carbohydrate chains that are only on the outer surface
options.explanation: Labelling sides clarifies which direction faces outward, which is important because carbohydrate chains are only on the extracellular surface and the bilayer has an asymmetric distribution of components.

options.text: It is purely decorative and has no scientific significance for understanding membrane structure at all
options.explanation: Labelling sides is scientifically important because the membrane is asymmetric, with different components on each surface.

options.text: It helps to show that the membrane is the same on both sides with no structural differences present
options.explanation: The membrane is not identical on both sides; carbohydrate chains and some proteins are asymmetrically distributed.

options.text: It is only necessary for plant cell diagrams because animal cells have no defined membrane orientation
options.explanation: All cell membranes have a defined orientation with distinct extracellular and intracellular sides, regardless of cell type.

toLevel3.question: What would be missing from a plasma membrane diagram that only shows phospholipids arranged as a bilayer?

options.text: Proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrate chains
options.explanation: A complete membrane diagram requires transmembrane and peripheral proteins, cholesterol between phospholipids, and carbohydrate chains forming glycoproteins and glycolipids.

options.text: Nothing, because phospholipids are the only component of the plasma membrane structure
options.explanation: The plasma membrane also contains proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates, all of which should be included in a complete diagram.

options.text: Only ribosomes, which are embedded throughout the membrane bilayer in all cell types
options.explanation: Ribosomes are not embedded in the plasma membrane; the missing components are proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrate chains.

options.text: Only the cell wall, which surrounds the plasma membrane in all cell types universally
options.explanation: Not all cells have a cell wall (animal cells lack one). The missing plasma membrane components are proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates.

toLevel3.question: Glycolipids are formed when carbohydrate chains are attached to lipid molecules on the outer surface of the plasma membrane.
toLevel3.explanation: Glycolipids are lipid molecules with carbohydrate chains attached, found on the extracellular surface of the plasma membrane.

options.text: True
False

toLevel3.question: Cholesterol is drawn between {{blank:1}} in the bilayer and helps regulate membrane {{blank:2}}.
Carbohydrate chains are found on the {{blank:1}} surface of the membrane and are involved in cell {{blank:2}}.
A complete membrane diagram includes a phospholipid {{blank:1}}, proteins, cholesterol and {{blank:2}} chains.

toLevel4.question: A student draws a membrane with phospholipid heads facing inward and tails facing outward. What consequence would this arrangement have?

options.text: The hydrophobic tails would be exposed to water and the membrane would not form a stable bilayer
options.explanation: Hydrophobic tails exposed to the aqueous environment would be energetically unfavourable, preventing the formation of a stable bilayer structure.

options.text: The membrane would function normally because the orientation of phospholipids does not matter
options.explanation: Phospholipid orientation is critical; the hydrophilic heads must face outward towards water for the bilayer to be stable.

options.text: The membrane would become fully permeable and allow all substances to cross without restriction
options.explanation: The reversed orientation would prevent stable bilayer formation entirely, not simply change permeability.

options.text: The membrane would become stronger and more rigid than the correct orientation would produce
options.explanation: The reversed arrangement would be unstable, not stronger. Hydrophobic tails in contact with water is energetically unfavourable.

toLevel4.question: A membrane diagram is missing cholesterol. How would this affect the membrane's properties in a living cell?

options.text: The membrane would have poorly regulated fluidity, becoming too fluid at high temperatures and too rigid at low temperatures
options.explanation: Cholesterol buffers membrane fluidity by preventing excessive movement at high temperatures and excessive rigidity at low temperatures.

options.text: The membrane would function identically because cholesterol has no significant role in membrane properties
options.explanation: Cholesterol plays an important role in regulating membrane fluidity and stability.

options.text: The membrane would immediately dissolve because cholesterol is the primary structural component of all membranes
options.explanation: Phospholipids are the primary structural component; cholesterol regulates fluidity but is not the main structural element.

options.text: The membrane would become completely impermeable to all substances, blocking all molecular transport
options.explanation: Removing cholesterol affects fluidity regulation, not overall permeability to all substances.

toLevel4.question: Compare a diagram that shows only transmembrane proteins with one that includes both transmembrane and peripheral proteins. Which is more accurate?

options.text: The diagram with both types, because the membrane contains transmembrane and peripheral proteins
options.explanation: A complete and accurate membrane diagram includes both transmembrane proteins spanning the bilayer and peripheral proteins attached to one surface.

options.text: The diagram with only transmembrane proteins, because peripheral proteins are not part of the plasma membrane
options.explanation: Peripheral proteins are part of the plasma membrane; they are attached to one surface and perform important functions.

options.text: Both diagrams are equally accurate because protein type does not affect membrane structure or function
options.explanation: The two protein types have different positions and functions, so including both provides a more complete representation.

options.text: Neither diagram is accurate because proteins are not found in the plasma membrane at all
options.explanation: Proteins are essential components of the plasma membrane, as described by the fluid mosaic model.

toLevel4.question: A student labels a structure on the intracellular side of their membrane diagram as a glycoprotein. What error have they made?

options.text: Glycoprotein carbohydrate chains are found on the extracellular side, not the intracellular side
options.explanation: The carbohydrate chains of glycoproteins face the extracellular environment where they function in cell recognition and signalling.

options.text: The label is correct because glycoproteins are evenly distributed on both sides of the membrane
options.explanation: Glycoprotein carbohydrate chains are specifically located on the extracellular surface, not on both sides.

options.text: The error is that glycoproteins are only found inside the nucleus, not on the plasma membrane
options.explanation: Glycoproteins are found on the plasma membrane, specifically with their carbohydrate chains on the extracellular surface.

options.text: The label is correct because all carbohydrate chains face the cytoplasm inside the cell
options.explanation: Carbohydrate chains of glycoproteins and glycolipids face the extracellular environment, not the cytoplasm.

toLevel4.question: Apply your knowledge of membrane structure to explain why a channel protein must span the entire bilayer to function.

options.text: It must connect both sides of the membrane to create a passage for substances to cross
options.explanation: Channel proteins need to span both layers of the bilayer to form a continuous passage from the extracellular environment to the cytoplasm.

options.text: It only needs to be on one surface because substances can jump across the bilayer gap unaided
options.explanation: Hydrophilic substances cannot cross the hydrophobic interior alone; the channel must span the entire bilayer to provide a continuous pathway.

options.text: Spanning the bilayer is optional because channel proteins work by dissolving the membrane temporarily
options.explanation: Channel proteins do not dissolve the membrane; they provide a physical passage through the bilayer by spanning both layers.

options.text: Channel proteins must be on both surfaces simultaneously but do not need to be connected together
options.explanation: Channel proteins must form a continuous passage through the membrane, requiring them to physically span and connect both layers.

toLevel4.question: How would you modify a basic membrane diagram to show that the membrane is described by the fluid mosaic model?

options.text: Include diverse components like proteins, cholesterol and carbohydrates scattered throughout the bilayer
options.explanation: The mosaic aspect is shown by including a variety of different molecules (proteins, cholesterol, carbohydrates) distributed throughout the phospholipid bilayer.

options.text: Draw all phospholipids in a perfectly regular grid with no other components present at all
options.explanation: A regular grid of only phospholipids does not represent the diverse, mosaic-like arrangement described by the fluid mosaic model.

options.text: Remove all proteins and show only phospholipids to emphasise the fluid nature of the bilayer
options.explanation: Removing proteins would make the diagram incomplete; the mosaic aspect requires diverse molecular components.

options.text: Draw the membrane as a single straight line with labels for each component listed beside it
options.explanation: A single line does not represent the bilayer structure or the diverse arrangement of components described by the model.

toLevel4.question: A diagram shows a protein sitting entirely on the outer surface of the membrane. What type of protein is this?

options.text: Peripheral protein
options.explanation: Peripheral proteins are attached to one surface of the membrane and do not span the bilayer, unlike transmembrane proteins.

options.text: Transmembrane protein
options.explanation: Transmembrane proteins span the entire bilayer; a protein on only one surface is a peripheral protein.

options.text: Channel protein
options.explanation: Channel proteins are a type of transmembrane protein that span the bilayer to create passages; a surface protein is peripheral.

options.text: Glycolipid molecule
options.explanation: Glycolipids are lipid molecules with carbohydrate chains, not proteins sitting on the membrane surface.

toLevel4.question: If phospholipid tails faced {{blank:1}}, the membrane would be unstable because the tails are {{blank:2}} and repelled by water.
A channel protein must {{blank:1}} the entire bilayer to create a continuous {{blank:2}} for substances to cross.
Glycoprotein carbohydrate chains face the {{blank:1}} environment where they function in cell {{blank:2}}.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate why drawing the plasma membrane is considered a more rigorous assessment of understanding than selecting correct labels from a list.

options.text: Drawing requires understanding spatial relationships between components, not just recalling their names
options.explanation: Drawing requires students to demonstrate how components relate to each other spatially, such as head orientation, tail direction, and protein positioning, which tests deeper understanding.

options.text: Drawing and labelling test exactly the same level of understanding with no difference in cognitive demand
options.explanation: Drawing requires spatial reasoning and understanding of component relationships, which is more cognitively demanding than simply recognising correct labels.

options.text: Labelling is actually more rigorous because it requires memorisation of all technical vocabulary terms
options.explanation: While labelling requires vocabulary recall, drawing requires both vocabulary knowledge and understanding of how components are arranged relative to each other.

options.text: Drawing is less rigorous because students can draw anything and still receive full marks on assessments
options.explanation: Membrane drawings are assessed for accuracy of component placement, orientation, and relationships, requiring genuine understanding.

toLevel5.question: A student's membrane diagram shows all proteins clustered on one side. Analyse what this suggests about their understanding of the fluid mosaic model.

options.text: They may not understand that proteins are distributed throughout the bilayer in a mosaic pattern
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model describes proteins as scattered throughout the membrane in a varied pattern. Clustering them on one side suggests a misunderstanding of the mosaic distribution.

options.text: Their diagram is correct because all proteins are naturally found on only one side of the membrane
options.explanation: Proteins are distributed throughout the membrane; some are transmembrane, others are peripheral, and they are not all clustered on one side.

options.text: Their diagram shows a perfect understanding of how membrane components are arranged in all cells
options.explanation: Clustering proteins on one side does not accurately represent the distributed mosaic pattern described by the fluid mosaic model.

options.text: Protein distribution does not matter in membrane diagrams because only phospholipid arrangement is assessed
options.explanation: Protein distribution is an important aspect of the fluid mosaic model and should be accurately represented in membrane diagrams.

toLevel5.question: Compare a membrane diagram that includes glycoproteins and glycolipids with one that omits them. What biological understanding is lost when they are excluded?

options.text: The role of carbohydrates in cell recognition and signalling is not represented
options.explanation: Glycoproteins and glycolipids are essential for cell-to-cell recognition and signalling. Omitting them removes this important functional aspect from the diagram.

options.text: No understanding is lost because glycoproteins and glycolipids have no biological function at all
options.explanation: Glycoproteins and glycolipids play crucial roles in cell recognition, immune response, and cell signalling.

options.text: The structural integrity of the bilayer cannot be shown without glycoproteins and glycolipids present
options.explanation: Bilayer structure is maintained by phospholipids and cholesterol; glycoproteins and glycolipids function in recognition and signalling.

options.text: Only the transport function is lost because glycoproteins are the primary transport proteins in membranes
options.explanation: Glycoproteins primarily function in cell recognition and signalling; transport is carried out by channel and carrier proteins.

toLevel5.question: Analyse how the asymmetric distribution of components in the plasma membrane relates to its functions.

options.text: Different components on each side allow the membrane to perform distinct functions on the extracellular and intracellular surfaces
options.explanation: Carbohydrate chains on the outside enable cell recognition, while intracellular peripheral proteins can interact with the cytoskeleton, demonstrating that asymmetry supports specialised functions.

options.text: The membrane is perfectly symmetrical with identical composition on both surfaces at all times
options.explanation: The membrane is asymmetric, with carbohydrate chains only on the extracellular surface and different protein distributions on each side.

options.text: Asymmetry is a drawing error and has no biological significance for membrane function in living cells
options.explanation: Asymmetry is a real and important feature of biological membranes that supports their diverse functions.

options.text: All components must be identical on both sides for the membrane to function as a semi-permeable barrier
options.explanation: Semi-permeability is maintained by the phospholipid bilayer regardless of surface asymmetry; the asymmetry supports additional functions.

toLevel5.question: A student draws cholesterol molecules only on the outer layer of the membrane. Evaluate this placement.

options.text: This is incorrect because cholesterol is found between phospholipids in both layers of the bilayer
options.explanation: Cholesterol molecules are interspersed among phospholipids in both layers of the bilayer, not restricted to one layer.

options.text: This is correct because cholesterol only interacts with the extracellular environment directly
options.explanation: Cholesterol is embedded within the bilayer between phospholipid tails in both layers and does not interact directly with the extracellular environment.

options.text: This is correct because cholesterol is only found on the same side as the carbohydrate chains
options.explanation: Cholesterol is distributed in both layers of the bilayer, not restricted to the side with carbohydrate chains.

options.text: Cholesterol placement does not matter in membrane diagrams because it is an optional component
options.explanation: Cholesterol is an important membrane component and should be accurately drawn in both layers of the bilayer.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate how the concept of the phospholipid bilayer as a self-assembling structure explains why membranes can repair themselves after minor damage.

options.text: Hydrophobic interactions drive phospholipids to spontaneously rearrange and seal gaps in the bilayer
options.explanation: The bilayer self-assembles because hydrophobic tails are driven away from water. After minor damage, these same forces cause phospholipids to move and seal gaps spontaneously.

options.text: Membranes cannot repair themselves and must be entirely rebuilt by the cell after any form of damage
options.explanation: The fluid nature and self-assembling properties of the bilayer allow phospholipids to move and seal minor disruptions without complete rebuilding.

options.text: Repair occurs because proteins actively pull phospholipids into position using energy from ATP molecules
options.explanation: Self-repair of minor damage is driven by spontaneous hydrophobic interactions, not by active protein-mediated processes.

options.text: The membrane cannot self-assemble and requires external enzymes to arrange every phospholipid individually
options.explanation: Phospholipid bilayers can self-assemble spontaneously due to the hydrophobic effect, without requiring external enzymes for basic assembly.

toLevel5.question: Compare a diagram of a plasma membrane from a cell at body temperature with one from a cell exposed to very low temperatures. What differences in component arrangement might you expect?

options.text: At low temperatures, phospholipid tails would pack more tightly and the membrane would be less fluid
options.explanation: Low temperatures cause phospholipid tails to pack more closely together, reducing membrane fluidity. Cholesterol helps buffer this effect but cannot fully prevent it.

options.text: Temperature has no effect on membrane structure or the arrangement of any membrane components
options.explanation: Temperature significantly affects membrane fluidity by changing how tightly phospholipid tails pack together.

options.text: At low temperatures, all proteins would detach from the membrane and float freely in the cytoplasm
options.explanation: While reduced fluidity may affect protein mobility, proteins do not simply detach from the membrane at low temperatures.

options.text: At low temperatures, the phospholipid heads would become hydrophobic and reverse their orientation
options.explanation: Temperature changes do not alter the chemical properties of phospholipid heads; they remain hydrophilic regardless of temperature.

toLevel5.question: Assess the importance of including both structural and functional labels when drawing a plasma membrane diagram for an exam response.

options.text: Structural labels identify components while functional labels show understanding of their roles, demonstrating deeper knowledge
options.explanation: Including both types of labels shows that a student can identify membrane components and explain their functions, which demonstrates a more complete understanding.

options.text: Only structural labels are needed because functions cannot be shown in a static two-dimensional diagram
options.explanation: Functional labels can annotate structural drawings to explain the roles of components, adding depth to the diagram.

options.text: Only functional labels are needed because the structure of the membrane is not assessed in VCE Biology
options.explanation: Both structure and function of the plasma membrane are assessed in VCE Biology; structural labels are essential.

options.text: Labels of any kind are unnecessary because the drawing itself fully communicates all structural and functional information
options.explanation: Labels are necessary to identify and explain components clearly; a drawing alone may be ambiguous without labels.
